movie_review_blurb: Empty Nest doesn't offer anything new in the style Ingmar Bergman made so famous, but the film captures your heart thanks to the fine acting of its two main characters and Burman's deft hand.
'Sin ton ni son,' is a Spanish language phrase meaning without rhyme or reason, and obviously Sin ton ni Sonia has neither.
Fails to capture the anguish and struggles of an ultra-Orthodox Jew adapting to a more secular world.
A charming and somewhat engaging film.
Though the story is engaging, the writing and acting are as unsophisticated.
One shallow film, that quickly returns to where it started: Zero.
A mystical fairy tale by Alexander Rogozhkin as beautiful as it is tender.
A film that starts dark enough to be memorable but soon disintegrates into a farce.
Passionada is not as passionate as you may suspect. It's just a tender story about how opposites attract, and how much the nation is opening toward those who are different.
Sometimes engaging, sometimes amusing and ultimately surprising.
A modern and mature story about love and loving, a film as intelligent as it is charming.
It may be based on a true story, but another filmmaker told it before -- and better.
The film makes you take sides, and herein lies its attraction.
The stories touch our sensibilities, but the documentary never sugarcoats the childrens' experiences.
movie_title: Secret Lives: Hidden Children and Their Rescuers During WWII (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Cinematography spoils El Tigre's fun.
Even in its most tedious scenes, Russian Ark is mesmerizing.
The film is art in all its visual splendor, and no matter how confusing the historic story line may be to Westerners -- and it is -- the images on screen more than compensate for the faults.
A disappointment.
movie_title: He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not (2002)

movie_review_blurb: In between all the emotional seesawing, it's hard to figure the depth of these two literary figures, and even the times in which they lived. But they fascinate in their recklessness.
movie_title: Les enfants du siècle (The Children of the Century) (1999)

movie_review_blurb: The plot grows thin soon, and you find yourself praying for a quick resolution.
movie_title: God Is Great and I'm Not (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A chilling documentary that draws its impact purely on Junge's personal testimony.
There are no big-name actors and no fancy camera work. But that's what makes it interesting.
The film has good actors and enough quirky moments to keep it interesting.
Watching these two actors play against each other so intensely, but with restraint, is a treat.
movie_title: Comment j'ai tué mon père (My Father and I) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Even if the case against Kissinger is not fully convincing, the documentary keeps you glued to your seat and thinking long after you've left the theater.
It's a lot of fun.
A fantastic vehicle for three seasoned actors given the chance to play juicy roles at this stage of their lives.
Slow-moving but utterly delightful.
Told without drama, as if this were just an ordinary family, it is the subtleties of the details that win you over.
What starts as a satire of the methodical, modernity-seeking society in Sweden ends as a heartwarming dramatic comedy in Norway.
Poignant and beautiful.
As a light, easy, hardly thought-provoking 98 minutes at the cinema, it somewhat satisfies.
Empathy, despite its entertaining and insightful dialogue, can also be a bore.
This film by Andrei Zvyagintsev touches a nerve.
An extraordinary movie that ruffled many feathers when it first came out. Almost 40 years later, it retains the poignancy it delivered back then.
movie_title: The Battle of Algiers (La Battaglia di Algeri) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: An engaging and poignant film, one that could only be done by an insider.
Here was the making of a dark thriller that unfortunately director Omri Levy doesn't know how to sustain.
Despite its flaws, The Gatekeeper will keep you engaged.
It's beautiful to look at, but you must have patience to enjoy it.
Reminds us of previous events in the country's history, as told by a Haitian who impresses us as someone honestly looking for nothing more than peace.
A swinging London club; the breakup of a famous performing couple; a well-known dancer being replaced by one younger and more exotic; a murder. All juicy fodder for plot, and it's a good thing.
Bergman's debut feature is tender yet disturbing, sad yet at times funny.
The story is as predictable as a hot summer in South Florida, but if you're in need of comfort, Le Papillon is a good choice.
Mehta manages to make her film not only palatable, but a real pleaser.
Coupling the plot with the presentation -- and the appealing cinematography -- makes AKA a film not to miss.
It is a stunning work that captures with elegance -- and touches of lyricism -- the challenge of finding the man through the artist.
Will touch everyone with its haunting sounds and images.
One of Lombardi's finer films.
movie_title: Ojos Que No Ven (What the Eye Doesn't See) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It is a treat to see Sharif back on the screen and Boulanger is a pleasure to watch.
movie_title: Monsieur Ibrahim et les fleurs du Coran (Monsieur Ibrahim) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Longer than 2 1/2 hours, there's too much to sort out and the confusion becomes annoying.
Despite its fleshy title, Gleize's film is a feast for the mind.
An intimate tale of how a group of strangers scarred by the past and with heavy personal burdens attempts to break the years of mistrust and suspicions built up during the war years.
A fascinating look at events mostly unknown to outsiders.
Has enough good stuff to make it enjoyable.
Although the unrelenting pursuit of making the Vatican listen becomes a bit tiresome, the portrayals of the two men by Tukur and Kassovitz are engaging.
Though intrepid in exploring an attraction that crosses sexual identity, Ozpetek falls short in showing us Antonia's true emotions ... But at the very least, His Secret Life will leave you thinking.
Despite its many infuriating flaws -- not the least of which is Amy's self-absorbed personality -- Amy's O's honesty will win you over.
movie_title: Amy's O (Amy's Orgasm) (Why Love Doesn't Work) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: In a way, the film feels like a breath of fresh air, but only to those that allow it in.
movie_title: To Be and to Have (Etre et Avoir) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Maelstrom is strange and compelling, engrossing and different, a moral tale with a twisted sense of humor.
[L]ed by the wooden, unattractive Ingrid de Souza as Fernanda, the film has no place to go but down.
Fails to deliver either a social message or a good story.
An engaging and powerful portrayal of puberty gone awry.
A film with a few floundering moments that becomes a powerful description of what it means to be intimate.
Dark Blue World's warm story and beautiful photography almost hits the mark, and it has a great ending.
This is the kind of European film you rarely see anymore, with characters and circumstances that are easily debatable. Two viewers may never reach the same conclusion about the film.
La ville est tranquille is not depressing, but a sense of sadness permeates the film. As dramatic as it is, Guediguian's point is well taken: this town will remain quiet.
movie_title: The Town Is Quiet (La Ville est tranquille) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps it will prompt some researchers not only to learn of the symptoms but to look further at the cause.
Ultimately feels like tiny films glued together by events that often test plausibility.
A human story told with taste and simplicity. Better still, it is not maudlin.
Martel glues together a disjointed picture of a society where tension lies only skin deep.
The slow-moving film fails to capture the depth and intensity of what it means to battle political censure and depression.
movie_title: Smell of Camphor, Fragrance of Jasmine (2001)

movie_review_blurb: After The Others, The Art of Dying feels like the designer bags you buy at the flea market.
An engrossing film that attempts to unearth a dark period of African history and the short-lived tenure of Lumumba's power.
Ratcatcher goes straight to the head.
Even when the bickering diminishes the impact of the story, Wiener himself makes Fighter another interesting story to come out of World War II atrocities.
It's all very sweet, but the film goes in too many directions.
An antidote to the chaotic world that surrounds us, a place of beauty where humanity and nature are at its most basic.
A fascinating peek not only at the world of opera but also at the discipline, artistry and the pride of the Chinese.
The gripping A Love Divided will leave you taking sides, whether or not that was the film's intent.
The film delights the eye and soothes the nerves.
movie_title: The Vertical Ray of the Sun (Mua he chieu thang dung) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: The film is a charmer, filled with homey details that make you nostalgic for a warm and spicy tortilla soup.
Unfortunately, what you'll remember most are a pretty face and the hot and steamy sex scenes. That is not enough.
Thanks to a superb cast headed by the popular Brazilian actress Regina Casé, this unorthodox tale is ultimately believable.
Who would have thought a German comedy could be light, charming and devoid of intellectual snobbery?
This heavy-on-slapstick film is imperfect -- many details don't add up -- but it still is a lot of fun.
Keeps you glued to its images of helplessness, acceptance of sub-human conditions and the effects of drugs on malleable minds.
It provides an honest look at a community striving to anchor itself in new grounds.
The power of Shanghai Ghetto, a documentary by Dana Janklowicz-Mann and Amir Mann, rests in the voices of men and women, now in their 70s, who lived there in the 1940s.
The stunning cinematography, made crisper by present-day technology, and the film's overall visual concept continue to make your jaw drop with admiration.

The best indication of the film's pretentiousness comes from recurrent images of a book with blank pages, as if to point out that Godard has nothing to say, but so what? Let's throw in a few images and people will come anyway.
movie_title: In Praise Of Love (Éloge de l'amour) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The Bank, despite its faulty finale, is a fun and thrilling ride.
Though far from perfect -- the film is predictable -- Satin Rouge is a refreshing view of a foreign culture.
Carrera gets solid performances from the strong cast led by García Bernal.
A gripping documentary that reveals how deep the antagonism lies in war-torn Jerusalem.
Bread, My Sweet has so many flaws it would be easy for critics to shred it. It may even fall into the category of Films You Love to Hate. I admit it, I hate to like it.
There's much tongue in cheek in the film and there's no doubt the filmmaker is having fun with it all.
movie_title: Akai Hashi No Shita Noo Nurui Mizu (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A warm, funny, engaging film.
In Stine Stengade's intensely engaging performance, Kira is always one step away from the abyss, although, without apparent effort, she manages to hang on.
Painted with broad strokes but with a palette of rich, colorful details.
In Auteil's less dramatic but equally incisive performance, he's a charismatic charmer likely to seduce and conquer.
Too many improbabilities and rose-colored situations temper what could've been an impacting film.
Jacquot's Tosca is a treat.
A different movie -- sometimes tedious -- by a director many viewers would like to skip but film buffs should get to know.
While Cacoyannis' film may not be totally faithful to the master's pen, for literature students and theater lovers, this Cherry Orchard is a rare treat.
Beautiful to watch and holds a certain charm.
A gripping psychological thriller that, while lacking the power of Funny Games, is still the work of a master.
It has the elegance associated with haute cuisine, so it rises a level above your typical Hollywood chick flick.
Metaphors abound, but it is easy to take this film at face value and enjoy its slightly humorous and tender story.
Medem may have disrobed most of the cast, leaving their bodies exposed, but the plot remains as guarded as a virgin with a chastity belt. That's why Sex and Lucia is so alluring.
Seldom has the elegant past of 18th century royal life married modern filmmaking with the grace and sophistication of Eric Rohmer's L'anglaise et le duc.
Viewers are asked so often to suspend belief that were it not for Holm's performance, the film would be a total washout.
It is heartwarming and often funny, but in its lightness somehow misses the mark.
It is easy to watch, yet at the end, unsatisfying.
Some scenes drag, but Seagull's Laughter is still delightful.
One well-choreographed, beautifully shot and definitely cool cops-and-robbers film.
It's a film that teases us with the realm of possibilities and a few really funny scenes.
Cynics may not fall for its melodrama, but Riding Alone is good for everyone else, including children.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This long documentary is captivating. Not because you're peeking at lives of real people, but because it captures the way time heals all wounds and how people find a way out of deep holes if they are determined to do so.
The cast doesn't look like a troupe of actors; it could easily be taken for an ordinary family with plenty of physical and psychological bumps and bruises, but always loving.
Grips you from beginning to end.

This beautiful tale of two sisters living in Sarcelles, a low-income Parisian suburb of mostly new immigrants, presents the darker side of religion while offering a candid view of an Orthodox Jewish family struggling to stay together.
A visual work of art and its simple story moves as effortlessly as the sands in a forsaken desert in northern Brazil.
Its lack of sentimentality and melodrama is what elevates this thriller to another level.
The cast of renegades is as appealing as ever.
Holds enough interest throughout to keep you entertained -- unless you're afraid of mice.
A captivating documentary.
Keeps you entertained throughout its two hours, which says a lot about Nunez's storytelling.
A gentle film about a lion of a man who, as a communist, was forced to leave Germany, lived almost penniless in Europe and America during the war and returned to his homeland in 1948.
Though the film would benefit from further cuts, Machuca still manages to convey the frailty of convictions and the difficulties of growing up -- be it a child or a nation.
The film is probably too slow, too silent and too long for most audiences. But look beyond the quietness, and you'll discover a three-gem jewel.
movie_title: Three Times (Zui hao de shi guang) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Enigmatic and mesmerizing.
movie_title: L' Ora di Religione (Il Sorriso di Mia Madre) (The Religion Hour) (My Mother's Smile) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: When you understand its message, the film takes on a different level.
movie_title: Up and Down (Horem Pádem) (Loop the Loop) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This Israeli film gives us an honest look at situations we never see in the news. It may have too many flaws to be a good film, but for its content, it is a winner.
Alberti loses the edge to become more manipulative. The cinematography still shows the quality of a talented filmmaker, but his determination to be noncommittal takes that quality down a notch.
With little dialogue and long takes depicting Sri Lanka's desolate landscape and even more desolate people, The Forsaken Land comes close to being unbearable to watch.
The good acting and believable characters build the kind of story you're drawn to.
Beautifully shot and well-acted.
In looking at Gyuri -- you see an indomitable spirit that rises above the horrors of his past.
Go for Zucker is far from a perfect film but it brings easy laughter and joy.
At times irrepressibly hilarious, Only Human milks every possibility of clash with dark humor.
The beautiful shots of San Francisco's lush Telegraph Hill are captivating by themselves, but the film's greatest achievement is its humanity.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Cheung makes her character work, despite a weak plot and script, both by director Assayas.
The storyline in The War Within is far from fluid and, at times, overwrought. But it doesn't stop the film from capturing one's interest.
Cuaron demonstrates his capacity as a director. The camera work is impressive, his sense of humor sharp, and the characters are well defined.
Whether one agrees with his point of view or not, it's a message worth hearing.
Tyrnauer succeeds in making a documentary in which man and his creations are one and the same. Yes, Valentino lives in opulence, but his gowns exist in that stratosphere too.
Hilariously funny while totally believable, Sixty Six also leaves you with a warm and fuzzy feeling. It is a father-son tale told with the details and care of someone who was there.
Even if you followed these events and know the details well, Shoot Down is quite revealing -- and moving.
Mauro's character is underwritten, but Michel Joelsas delivers a believable, pained lad capable of still being a child.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: You have to like James and his outlook on life. It may not be glamorous, but it's one that eventually allows James a higher lever of satisfaction.
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A film that is hard to forget.
Salawich's film is entertaining and leaves you with warm feelings from learning about this man who turned adversity into good for so many others.
In trying to be sensitive to such a controversial issue, O Jerusalem glazes over important events settling for mediocrity while giving a history lesson more appropriate for high school.
What the film does well is to make us part of the problem: After all we demand the lowest prices in everything we buy and that probably means it was made in China.

The beautiful scenery complements the intimate scenes even as the story becomes something we've all seen and read in so many books and films. Yet, its candid conversations about sexuality are what places Lawrence's protagonist in a class by herself.
Captures the essence of the period -- an intriguing, backward era in Spain -- but without the emotional impact that such a film requires.
Although Leconte allows for a certain warmth to run through the film, he thankfully stays away from sentimentality. Therein lays the charm.
Humor and politics finally converge in what the story is all about: finding the good in those different from you. It's a happy ending that can be enjoyed by all.

A good example of making the differences work for you. Deep down, this is a film about childhood dreams and the determination to make those dreams come true. With such a positive message, you can't help yodeling on your exit from the theater.
If only the writing matched the film's style and acting.
The Mother never fails to engage.
The Wind that Shakes the Barley is a multi-layered story, and the more you see those different aspects, the more you'll enjoy the film.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmakers want to cover all aspects of the individuals involved and the film sometimes digresses into side cases. Yet, as history goes, it is hard to present such an important event without showing the monumental evidence.
movie_title: Verdict on Auschwitz: The Frankfurt Trial 1963-1965 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Elevator to the Gallows is a treat for the film buff. Watching Moreau and Malle as they discover each other and a new trend in filmmaking, and listening to Miles Davis during their quest will remind you of what movies are all about.
movie_title: Elevator to the Gallows (Ascenseur pour l'échafaud) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: Full of subtle dark humor that won't make you bend with laughter but certainly may cause you to giggle.

In addition to the interesting camera work, the documentary's undeniable appeal comes in how close Longley gets to the characters, who are all male. They speak openly of the past, the U.S. forces, the uncertain future.

One of the most interesting parts of the documentary is Safdie's description of his relationship with Yitzhak Rabin, the assassinated prime minister of Israel who fought for a dialogue with the Palestinians.
movie_title: Moshe Safdie: The Power of Architecture (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Brother's Shadow is an enjoyable film about family matters. Each member of the cast owns his role and the story, despite its lapses, seems real.
Wrestling with Angels is personal and intimate, insightful about Kushner as well as instructive about his collection of works.
Quintessential David Mamet: brainy, playful, engaging.
Honest and incisive, a film without a message, just telling it like it is.
Rana's Wedding serves as a strong reminder of the difficulties the people of Jerusalem face every day.
The Iceberg is a riot, a quintessential French comedy with an improbable plot and an unbelievable cast of characters.
Going Shopping can make a wonderful outing for girlfriends. It's fun.
A touching film, providing a glimpse into yet another hidden story about the history of European Jews before the arrival of the Nazis.
A girl, a boy and a few days among reels of film: For a cinema lover it is heaven in celluloid.
As powerful as the plot sounds, the film still drags, losing steam as it develops.
Though Hooper falters on the side of manipulation, the story remains engrossing.
Everything in this film is as fake as a copied painting. We've seen it all before, and we've seen it done better.
Despite some nice shots of scenes converting into well-known art, Modigliani is plainly, badly directed.
Director Alain Corneau refrains from turning some of the bosses -- and their actions -- into caricatures. Even Amelie is never made to appear as a victim, just victimized.
A film that adapts the basic Russian classic and then breaks away in more ways than just the setting.
A weightless film. Worse still, McElwee's languid tone makes his journey lack conviction.
A provocative documentary on a life that could easily be described as a moving train.
movie_title: Howard Zinn: You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Yes Nurse, No Nurse is fun -- if you get into its groove.
movie_title: Ja zuster, nee zuster (Yes Nurse! No Nurse!) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: See it as a war romance, and you'll like it.
Carries a powerful, albeit not new, message. It is frightening.
A 60-minute- plus treasure that shouldn't be missed.
What a shame such a rich and tumultuous life gets such poor treatment.
A mesmerizing documentary about the rise and fall of a drug lord, perhaps the biggest there ever was.
movie_title: The Private Archives of Pablo Escobar (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Heart-warming fun it is, and heck, after getting to know its quirky people, it might not be that bad moving to Ste. Marie-la- Mauderne.
Nothing in it -- plot, dialogue or character development -- reaches today's standards of filmmaking.
Beautiful to look at but aimless as a broken compass.
The story sometimes slips into soapy territory, but when you think the schmaltz is going to ruin it, Yamada gives it just enough of a twist to make you realize this is not your regular romantic film.
It is pretty convincing in its argument that China has every intention of destroying the culture of Tibetans.
movie_title: Tibet: Cry of the Snow Lion (2003)

movie_review_blurb: As many times you consider A Day Without a Mexican a crude and underdeveloped parody, there are moments that it vindicates itself with on-the-money situations.
As it moves forward, this bleak parable of business and power teases you with possibilities.
The finely crafted film shows the complex needs and anxieties of a three-generation family living in a country that has undergone dramatic political and cultural changes.
Ushpizin may not turn out to be as popular as Miracle on 34th Street, but if you believe that miracles can happen, it is a perfect outing during the holidays.

If nothing else, watching the photogenic Clara Lago as Carol, the engaging Juan Jose Ballesta as Tomiche, the veteran Alvaro de Luna as Amalio and the talented Rosa Sarda as Maruja make up for some of the mistakes.
By the time you understand the meaning of its title, Sabiha Sumar's film has delivered an emotional punch.
I must admit that I came out of DiG! with a certain degree of admiration for Newcombe -- and for this documentary.
The beauty of Huo Ji Anqi's film transcends China's lush Hunan province to focus on the peace that comes from within.
movie_title: Postmen in the Mountains (Nashan naren nagou) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The film falls into a melodramatic and soapy love story that makes you cringe as much as the horrific scenes of the brutal circumcision.
It is the only film in which two of the great stars of the era -- Gloria Swanson and Rudolf Valentino -- appeared together. If only to see their on-screen chemistry, no film buff should miss it.
The Ninth Day is far from perfect, but is still thought-provoking and intriguing, a film that can begin its own kind of debate.
The film won't put you at the edge of your seat, but will keep your attention.
movie_title: De zaak Alzheimer (The Memory of a Killer) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A Frenchman may have thought of the story first, but this Korean film pays tribute to the original while perfectly standing on its own.
While not boring, it is too light to be taken seriously.
movie_title: The Perfect Crime (El Crimen Perfecto)(Crimen ferpecto) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Overall the acting as well as the cinematography is a treat.
movie_title: The Two of Us (Le vieil homme et l'enfant) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: This is an affair to forget.
For the uninformed, Zuria's film comes as a shocking revelation.
An engrossing psychological thriller.
The Alejandro Lozano film may lack the writing finesse shown by the Coen brothers or Quentin Tarantino, but the Latin touch makes up for the rough spots.

For those inclined to search for psychological twists, the film offers plenty of Freudian situations capable of provoking lengthy discussions. For the film buff, the discussions will turn to a Bergman still at the peak of his craft.
The film shows a capsule of American urban life where few outside the community venture in. Eason hands out an invitation to do so. Accept it willingly.
It's a story about sexism and inequalities, and were it not for its hokey ending, the film would've gained even more international recognition.

Where Middle of the World becomes more appealing is in showing life along the less-traveled roads of Brazil, a landscape of beauty and poverty, nomad lives and basic instincts in a determination to make the best of a lurid existence.
movie_title: The Middle of the World (O Caminho das Nuvens) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A character study that deserves viewing, thanks to the acting of its two principals.
movie_title: Light of My Eyes (Luce dei miei occhi) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The film deals with many serious issues, some of them only superficially, but Fox places them all in the context of the growing friendship between the two opposites.
It touches on a lot of different matters, yet you can't help having a good time watching it.
There are few moments when you're not totally absorbed by the film.
More than a thriller, the film is a portrait of the passions that drive ordinary people to kill and even worse, to accept the killing as something honorable.
Burman explored this world before in 2000's Waiting for the Messiah, but in Lost Embrace, his maturity results in a much tighter and engaging film.
It's the attention to small details that makes the characters so believable, especially in the way Smith delivers their sentiments: in quiet, personal moments.
There's a warmth to Inch' Allah Dimanche that transcends its many character-development flaws.
Filho seems to lose the thread of where he's going with the story.

Despite some banalities and Romen Avinian's slightly overdone Hamo, Vodka Lemon is a fresh breath of air, warmer than the icy village in which it takes place. You'll leave the theater with a wink and a smile.
It's a summer love story without heat and a coming-of-age story that never matures.
Alvarez's Evil Dead left many wondering what this visually talented director would do next. Inconsistent and offensive, Don't Breathe is not the follow-up many will have wanted.

The influence of the buddy comedies of Shane Black is obvious, but the film never reaches the heights of a film like Kiss, Kiss, Bang, Bang. War on Everyone is always funny, but it could have been so much more.
Hunter Gatherer is that rare film that sneaks around the corner and smashes headlong into the viewer.

Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows comes off as less a film and more a grouping of shortcuts to our collective cinematic and cultural unconscious. This time, you don't need to turn off the TV, you just don't have to go.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Phantasm: Ravager will disappoint the uninitiated, but those who are loyal will find enough to love.
Malick's camera was once drawn to the sky, as the light from above plays on the leaves. With Song to Song, he's simply seeking a backstage pass to hang with the cool kids.

With A Monster Calls, however, J.A. Bayona displays the knowledge, assurance, and wit of a filmmaker truly coming into his own. Entertaining, tonally impeccable, and heartbreaking, this is a monster movie with a very human heart.
It's a hilarious master class in self-referentiality, as well as an affectionate and reverential tribute to Tommy Wiseau and his mad creation.
Fits and Starts sometimes seems unable to handle character, story, and motivation at the same time.
As writers, the Nelms brothers have crafted a comedic crime narrative most akin to the Coen Brothers or Shane Black.
Split is one further step for Shyamalan on the road to cinematic redemption. We can only hope he continues to work at this level of production.
It's hard to give Mary Shelley's classic tale a new spin, but at least this movie has a great time while doing it. [Full review in Spanish]
Love, Rosie tries to tell an original love story, but it doesn't quite get there. [full review in Spanish]
You want to press pause, and just sit and take it in: The colors, the humor, the light, the surfaces; the simple pleasure of watching a master at work.

One of the things that distinguishes Herzog as a director is his profound capacity for empathy. His gift enables him to get deep inside his subjects, and he is rewarded with moments of stark revelation and clarity.
movie_title: Land of Silence and Darkness (Land des Schweigens und der Dunkelheit) (1973)

movie_review_blurb: There's an impressive, careful complexity to DarkBlueAlmostBlack that belies the inexperience of first-time director Daniel Sánchez Arévalo.
An Argentine film packed full of pain and suffering that nevertheless fails utterly to connect with its audience.
A complex look at the power and changeability of intimate relationships.
What's most impressive about The Lives of Others is how smoothly it blends politics with both the traditional elements of thrillers and unabashed sentimentality.
A disappointingly by-the-numbers effort from a filmmaker of rare and true genius.
Dryly funny throughout its first half, the film truly comes to life in its final 45 minutes.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A dark, nasty little movie that's never quite as deep or as clever as it imagines itself to be.
Apart from its sharp screenplay, This is England derives its power from a pair of extraordinary performances.
The problem with Time is that every character in the film is so fundamentally repulsive it's impossible to care about any of them.
It's both a revelation and a simple confirmation of everything you've ever believed, and an incredibly powerful, deeply emotional experience.
movie_title: Zidane, un Portrait du 21e Siècle (Zidane: A 21st Century Portrait) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Deeply sincere, laughably misjudged, and insultingly shallow.
Memorable for its constant, unexpected air of affection, and for the determined little boy at its center.
Landline seems to barely bear its own weight. But it's one of those movies that has something to say about cheating -- by cheaters.
The title is odd, but the film is odder. The film works so long as you're willing to allow that not all stories need a beginning, middle, and end, preferably in that order.
If all you know of cats is what you see on Facebook, you will be amazed by Kedi. If what you know about cats comes from your resident feline, you will be soothed and assured by Kedi.
Julieta interprets a woman's complex story, something Almadovar does so well, through a series of still lives: red frosting, a blue sweater -- a fine film.
Jackie is too focused to teach history to the young and too invasive to appeal to the old, who watched TV that November.
[Hello, My Name is Doris] is a largely unfunny movie about a sad sack woman.
[I Love You Both] is unpredictable and delightful, an amuse bouche.
The documentary packs a wallop of compassion and intelligence.
Gifted depends on the skill of Mckenna Grace to perform as the little math genius with sass. She and the film succeed admirably.
Ghostbusters, as directed by Paul Feig and written by him and Katie Dippold, is not about plot, but about seeing how the actors interact with each other and the special effects.
The Wikipedia entry on Williams' life has more energy, more sparks, than the whole of I Saw the Light. Hank Williams left a greater legacy than this film will.
Live by Night would make viewers sleep by night, too, except for the noise of gunshots and body-slams.
Loving carries a quiet energy of righteousness.
What does not play so true is the production value of Free State of Jones. So often the acting and enacting are wooden, the make-up a few smears of mud on a face. The film could have used subtitles.
Manchester by the Sea, while not a great film, is an honest lesson in grief.
Marguerite offers pathos bathed in luxury and delusion with a hint of compassion.
Max Rose adds little to the end-of-life theme, but it offers old-timers in a realistic look at old age, old love, and family affairs.
Gabriela Cowperthwaite has directed a heartfelt memorial to women and dog soldiers.
This film, running under 90 minutes, rightly deserves to be slotted in the category "slice of life."
Mia Madre may not cut fine facets on the gemstone of the theme, but still, it carries itself with integrity.
Miss Sloane is a Greek tragedy set in Washington, D.C. It is an admirable study in morals and character and deviousness -- and filmmaking.
Nocturnal Animals offers film as crisp, well-cut, tautly sewn, and artfully made to perfection.
Obit. dives deep, into the morgue, into writers' and editors' hearts and minds, into the dead. Obit.'s world is fascinating indeed.
The film, though uneven, presents a subculture worth considering.
Go for the broad humor of Rough Night; stay because that's what friends do.
Lo and Behold, a geek flick, approaches incomprehensibility at times for the un-nerdy, but it raises good questions.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Finding Dory is delightful, perfect waterworks for the beginning of summer for children and adults.
Equity is a film by women, about women -- lesbian and straight -- and starring women. Take note.
Eye in the Sky hops from place to place, decision to in-decision, from reason to emotion, to create heart-smacking tension.
Seasons is very, very beautiful to look at, but do not get so mesmerized by the visions and miss the message. Seasons is more than pretty.
20th Century Women doesn't entertain, not as a moment in time or as a study in 20th century women's characters.
A Ghost Story offers a new take on old themes of death and life and comes full circle.
A Monster Calls transcends its title and delivers its promises.
None of these moments would bring anyone to appreciate Emily Dickinson's passionate poetry.
A United Kingdom makes the most of a titbit of history. Aspects of this true story connect to all sorts of history well known, yet little of its history is known. This is a connect-the-dots history.
Abortion: Stories Women Tell is not balanced 50/50, pro/con. Just like the issue of abortion, the documentary and the women embrace a wide range.
One does not have to have a long history with Edina Monsoon and Patsy Stone to enjoy the film version of this friendship, a folie à deux.
Anthropoid does not re-write history. All does not end well. That's the best aspect of this tolerable film.
Sonia Braga plays Clara. She covers a range from sweetly adoring gramma to tough momma with chiding children, from a political beast to a woman longing for physical love.
Like most films of this genre, no matter the genders, Bad Moms has its funny, funny highlights and then long stretches of blah-de-blah-ness, but when it works, it works good.
Band Aid works well as an indie film, short and sharp with redeeming attributes.

The cinematography, aided by drones, shines forth from on high whether over dances or the land. The fairy-dusted costumes are fabulous. But, most of all, the moral holds true that love transcends looks.
Billy is so cliched as to be a photocopy.
Without a center, Café Society becomes a photo album with no device to pull these magnetic filings toward the middle. Once more with feeling, please. At various locations.
Captain Fantastic stands out as a film about being honest -- about mental illness, about religion and education, about politics and sex. It's brilliant.
Churchill is not just history but also a work of art.
Complete Unknown offers a bit of difference to a late summer scene, not a beach film nor a blockbuster.
For all the good acting on Jake Gyllenhaal's part, Demolition just does not nail the dismount.
Denial is awfully good, brilliantly edited, and successfully provocative.
Despicable Me 3 is thoroughly delightful, clever, and dear.
The film is not a grand exercise in maturation but in reality.
Dough is predictable: the two male protagonists become friends and protectors in the end. It has its sweet spots, but the film just never seems to come together.
The hardest part of this good documentary is watching Zappa, who defined music like no one else, facing the prostate cancer that ultimately took his in life 1993.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Elvis & Nixon should be so funny is delightful -- especially to Americans of a certain age.
Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them is just fabulously fantastic.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Silence is a stunning, unforgettable, even timely film about the Martyrs of Japan.
Cesc Gay directed Truman with understanding but without drippy sentiment.
Snatched remains blessedly short and mostly unfunny.
George Clooney directs, very steadily, a pedestrian pace through fire to that idyllic end.
Directors Catherine Fund and Daresha Kyi skillfully interwove newsreels and a long interview reel with interviews with the people in Chavela's world...
Under the direction of Simon Curtis, Goodbye Christopher Robin plays on heartfelt sentiments without sinking to the sentimental.
Jon Lucas and Scott Moore, who wrote and directed Bad Moms and The Hangover, know their audience, and in A Bad Moms Christmas, they balance the nasty with the poignant.
Murder on the Orient Express drags, which is good if you need a nap, but not so good if you seek excitement and mystery.
... watching the merry and bright film about the story's origin almost makes me want to see the show again, or maybe read the brief book by Charles Dickens. That's how delightful the movie is.
"Novitiate" is not great, but it is very good at presenting a notable time in church history.
Last Flag Flying provides broad brush strokes and nuances and rewards with every line, whether comic or tragic.
The children... behaved, entertained by it all -- the story and the songs. Me? Not so much.
Elie Harboe portrays multi-layered Thelma with precision, and she's paired well with Kaya Wilkins as Anja.
It refuses to find a focus, almost as if it's been on its own Ferris wheel and is dizzy with misdirection and indecision.
It's slow, but when it has something to say, it's worth listening to the philosophy of Lucky, a 90-year-old gar in his underwear.
Everything about the film is exemplary and would fit well on a double bill of history with Dunkirk.
"All the Money in the World" moves swiftly and ironically to tell a story of benighted values meeting headfirst against maternal loyalty.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Good news! This sequel is very nearly as good as the first version of the story of a bear in London.
Along with Susan Rice, this team manifests President Obama's exhortation that we must give diplomacy a chance to succeed.
Perhaps the most stunning short is the 22-minute "Watu Wote: All of Us" from Germany.
Excellent animated, Oscar-nominated shorts...
[Director Sall]Potter, who also directed "Tango Lesson," "Orlando," and "Ginger and Rosa," puts so much into the excellence of "The Party" that it's hard to tease apart.
... horribly violent, horribly sexualized exploitation version of Mad Magazine's "Spy v. Spy."
"Game Night" is a hot mess, but there are those laughs, and they're surely worth something, right?
It is a truthful, heart-breaking movie that never veers far from the reality of life's tragic demands.
"Loveless" is hard to watch, but it does encourage hugging every child you see afterwards.
"Tom of Finland," a fantastic film in more ways than one, peers into another world with honesty and ferocity as well as admiration.

Michael Gracy's direction of Jenny Bicks' and Bill Condon's script is spectacular, warm, and grand. "The Greatest Showman" proves that Gracy understands both film and musical as genres of show business.
Director Michael Roberts, a fashion writer by trade, has produced a fluff piece, albeit a pretty one.
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Reginald Hudson directed the film with an agenda, but the flawed film works beyond that goal.
Shot is not sophisticated, but it is truthful, which is, after all, the basis of most clichés.
Snowden is definitely an Oliver Stone movie, for it asks the audience to question and seek.
Much of the Scottish tongue is impossible to understand, but where the words lag, the pictures fill. Davies' direction makes Sunset Song meaningful.
Sing along. Swiss Army Man is solidly unpredictable.
The admirable animation is by DreamWorks Animation. The Boss Baby dandily delights kiddo's and adulties alike.
The Dinner is a complex moral fable.
[First Monday] is a good-enough doc if not an exemplary one.
The film is entertaining but not revelatory enough. There's little doubt an even more horrifying story lies beneath.
The Glass Castle tortures more than graces.
The Hollars fails but not miserably. It has its moments and its good intentions. So why doesn't it work?
The Journey offers moments of humor and waltzes of grace and anger in a film of an imagined journey.
This little film is a bagatelle, and a juicy little one. Pray for it.
Victoria and Abdul defines the biopic "based on a true story." Not one single false step. No blurred foci.
The Ottoman Lieutenant adds little to history while shooting at historical romance.
The Only Living Boy in New York focuses on cheating. It doesn't succeed utterly, but its trying hard.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Trip to Spain offers dry humor, word play, and adolescent behavior.
The film explains so terribly much about then, 1947, as well as now, 2017.
Home Again almost begs to be made fun of.
The Promise successfully presents Armenian history through romance.
The Man Who Knew Infinity brings to life a genius long overdue for recognition.
Wind River is violent and hard to watch, but gripping and telling with effective music.
I took the loveliest little nap during the screening of Tulip Fever.
With its buoyant storytelling, witty exchanges, and charming young characters, Sing Street is an immensely enjoyable film.
Therapy for a Vampire makes fun of vampires, but you have to love them enough to laugh at them. Otherwise, you have to have elastic eyes that roll well.
movie_title: Therapy for a Vampire (Der Vampir auf der Couch) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Director Lone Scherfig keeps the story true and zippy with extra ounces of reality. Their Finest is really fine.
The Wedding Plan won Israel's award for Best Film, for very good reasons.
This film has been sold as a bosom-buddy movie, with the stars Tina Fey and Margo Robbie as snipers. It is much more than that, much more than one-liners.
The grandparent of the screwball comedy sub-genre, and arguably Frank Capra's best film.
It all feels quite lovely and seems an achievement unto itself, to be allowed to soak in all this calm and tenderness.
Maria's interactions with film remind us of the most basic echelons of the filmic miracle-the miracles of reflection, projection, of light and seeing-and invite us into the excitement they hold.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What makes Jody Lee Lipes documentary so interesting - even transfixing at times - is the fact that nothing is editorialized or explained. There are no interviews or voice-overs.
Midway through the film, this level of unstructured naturalism crosses a threshold from boring to subtly compelling.
As an examination of how idealized conceptions of the ballerina have fed racial homogeneity in the industry, A Ballerina's Tale sticks with stuff we already know.
The portrait of the artist might be a bit uncritically rosy; still, this is a compelling dance film that captures the drive and passion of a key figure in contemporary choreography.
movie_title: Mr. Gaga: A True Story of Love and Dance (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While there's plenty of footage of Polunin executing multiple pirouettes and twisting acrobatically through the air, real ballet fans will lament the lack of evidence of emotion and artistry in his dancing.
Although the scenes are often dark and shrouded in mist, the film is replete with cinematic portraiture that sears itself into memory.
While this documentary could have been simply excessive and superficial, a sweet complexity and some darkness arrive toward the end.
One of the most revered films of all time...with hallmark performances from Peter O'Toole and Katharine Hepburn and the film debuts of Anthony Hopkins, Timothy Dalton, Nigel Terry and John Castle.
There is a charm and vitality to Raiders of the Ark, which Spielberg later admitted was "the first movie where I actually shot the movie without thinking".

Hitchcock was criticised for bring shallow psychology into the film (Hedren's character is afraid of the colour red) but some of their exchanges - the film was based on a novel by Winston Graham - are sharp and droll.
Down by Law is a delight, right down to the unexpected last scene.
Yippee-ki-yay, action fans.
A good musical with a lot of star power.
Van Dyke's energy is prodigious (especially when he leaps around with a gang of sooty chimney-sweeps on the London rooftops) and the songs are classics.
Although it is a spectacle film, the story of how a man takes on the tyranny of the Romans, with all sorts of horrible consequences to himself and his family, is powerful and gripping.
Winchester '73 changed the way cinema audiences saw the Western, because it featured a more complex idea of the noble hero of the west -- a man plagued by personal problems and violent impulses.
The scene in which Mr Memory is asked at the London Palladium "What are the 39 Steps?" remains one of 20th-century cinema's most gripping moments.
The really great thing about Airplane! is that the jokes undercut your expectations so deftly.
Steven Spielberg's film is not perfect: it plays its strongest card first, the middle section is slightly uneven, and there are sallies into sentimentality. But it is a modern war classic.
The interplay between the two leads is pure gold.
One of the most elegiac anti-war films ever made.
A sci-fi thriller of palpable, nerve-tingling tension, with Sigourney Weaver -- playing warrant officer Ellen Ripley -- in stunning form.
The chase sequences with government agents are tame but the film builds to a tense (and witty) conclusion at the Cheyenne Mountain nuclear bunker in Colorado Springs.
A masterpiece of dystopian science fiction on film.
A sombre, insightful, genre-reinventing western, directed by a filmmaker acutely aware of the western's history, its limitations and the dubious truths of its legends.
Contains one of the most charming dance sequences in cinema history.
Absorbing and historic.
This is a film that really does put our lives into perspective.
It is expertly edited and features an effective mix of archival footage, stills, and primary-source interviews.
A superior show-don't-tell effort from Finnish veterans Klaus Härö (director) and Tuomo Hutri (cinematographer).
Director Penny Lane's eccentric mixture of animation, archival shots, and live interviews scored a Sundance jury editing award and holds the attention.
With effective use of archival footage, modern interviews, and narration from survivors' journals, this doc will have viewers debating whodunit for hours over postscreening beers.
movie_title: The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came To Eden (2014)

movie_review_blurb: David Seidler, who wrote the screenplay, clearly did his homework, and the script is rich with dialogue uttered by the royal prototypes. Though he takes artistic license with certain facts, most such liberties are acceptable.
A modern classic? A brilliant vignette of a certain time and attitudes? A self-indulgent jeu d'esprit? One thing is certain: Richard E. Grant touched greatness.
The film's too long but when it works, as in a slickly choreographed military induction scene with Taymor's trademark giant puppets and carnival heads, it's exhilarating.
Pretty and rather dull.
The film's final unforgivable fault is its sheer, plodding dullness.
The downbeat mood convinces. What might have been tedious becomes an involving and nail-biting thriller.
Lovely performances all round create small-town competitiveness, frustrations and aspirations.
what Star Wars: The Clone Wars serves up is a rehashed Thunderbirds with a dash of Japanese anime.
Very funny.

Apart from a fascination with the hate-spitting mouth and throat of Lyubov Petrova's vocally pyrotechnic Queen of the Night, the visual gimmicks are individually tolerable. But they don't add up to anything particular.
There are prize-winning performances, seductive landscapes and hallucinatory shots of empty urban streets and shadowy interiors.
Not ground-breaking cinema, but a reminder that Christians can be tolerant and politicians principled.

American Lee Pace, from TV's Pushing Daisies, manages not one but several creditable English accents, sometimes unfortunately all in the same sentence, but whose emotional depth shows up this ball of fluff as insubstantial. Forgettable.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Not so much shapelessness as unvaried pace and emotional monotony spoil the engaging Small Engine Repair.
Gypsy Caravan - When the Road Bends evokes the US tour of Roma musicians whose astonishing diversity ranges from the Indian group with their bejewelled drag dancer to oompah-based Romanians.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Too shapeless and unplotted; and Mangan's not-too-ruffled rueful affability hails more from sitcom land.
U-Carmen hits the bull's eye, 'Toreador's or not.
A handful of brilliant performances makes Atonement worth seeing.
The ingredients of the German original Mostly Martha this time produce a cliché Chinese dish, forgotten a mere five minutes later.
Lurches on too long and topples into bathos.

It all rather sidesteps the question of why reluctant manager Samuel L. Jackson fails to demand a written disclaimer from a guest insisting on a room that has seen 56 deaths, including drowning in chicken soup.

Inertly plotted, haltingly paced, further embarrassed by Bob Hoskins in shyly lovesick mode, this broken-backed mess is fitfully illuminated by Anthony Head in a camp turn and the American Stockard Channing, her style as immaculate as her English accent.
Amateurishly written, scarcely acted tosh.
Eagle vs Shark lays on the whimsy with a trowel, almost smothering the real talent of an endearing cast. Provincial New Zealand.
Bollywood cheerfully meets - not Hollywood, exactly, more straight-to-video.

The central European tradition of failed aspirations, lost ideals and forlorn eccentrics goes back to early Forman, or indeed Chekhov, but the Latin Romanians bring their own awareness of the distant big city alternately beckoning and frightening.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Here is the French countryside at its most sinister: sideways glances from hostile natives, inbred yokels, disappearing children, corrupt politicians . . .
A rattling yarn exuberantly told, crunchingly violent but not too sadistic.
Quote not available.
The cinematography of Mátyás Erdély and András Nagy creates a nightmare subterranean world whose images linger after the sound and the (not very furious) fury have died away.
Two attempts at a movie spliced uneasily into one.
Pegg exudes his usual air of faint self-congratulation playing an unlikeable prat whom nobody in their right mind would prefer to the high- flying Azariah or indeed to anyone.
The types are such extremes that the partisans in the audience will continue to hate American brats and English snobs respectively, rapprochement between two sets of caricatures seeming unlikely.
A potentially corny plot is stylishly executed, abetted by a perfect cast.

The film shows a certain wit and a refined eclecticism: a director who in a few seconds combines Mozart's Clarinet Concerto, a quotation from Tennyson's In Memoriam and two monsters singing Beautiful Freak deserves watching.
Images of a thrusting male pelvis haunt the sensitive critic yet.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: LA 92 is a superb slice of history, the picture of a society that didn't know what was going to hit it as seething grudges came to a head, leaving the country stunned and perhaps changed forever.

Makes Guy Ritchie look like Dostoyevsky. Awful lines, bad acting - Danny Dyer's appearances stand out as dazzlingly professional, which says it all - unredeemed by a taste of Act 2 of Mozart's Figaro, a bizarre rococo touch.
Unconnected shreds of plot suggest severe editing at some stage and neither characters nor musical routines add up to much.
Unable to decide between being a romantic comedy, a zany farce or a thoughtful study of two emotionally repressed losers finding fulfilment, it ends up a mess; but an intriguing mess.
The problem is not length but shallowness.
It shows a painterly eye in frame after exquisitely judged frame, not afraid of economy and balance.
In White Lightnin', style and content meet, blend and writhe in the memory, a haunting nightmare.
The revelation of poverty, squalor and mental illness in LA's underclass is horrific. But the film suffers from uncertainty of tone.
A sub-plot features an orang-utan; it is no exaggeration to say that she is the most moving performer on screen.
Gently surreal to quizzically observant, fully deserving that lump.
Beautifully acted by Enrique Arreola and Cecilia Suárez, an actress both withdrawn and hauntingly luminous.

Sounds Like Teen Spirit has its share of emotional manipulation but this documentary on the Junior Eurovision leaves one saddened by so much hope, enthusiasm, ambition and energy expended on such a tacky concept.

Paul Morrison's evocation of the meeting in 1920s Madrid and subsequent tortuous relationship of the young Salvador Dalí, Luis Buñuel and Federico Garcia Lorca is such a labour of love that you forgive its incongruities.

Dazzlingly designed, the film salvages recognisable humanity in Rupert Friend's Chéri, aka the unromantic (to Anglo-Saxon ears) Fred. Elsewhere the movie is as insubstantial as a soufflé, and less intellectually challenging.
Much is hinted at, then skipped over. But Brando at least leaves us feeling there were real depths there: the angst was genuine, he took his art seriously.

But idolaters need fear no iconoclasm and newcomers no exclusion. The start of a presumably new chapter in the franchise is marked by affectionate respect tempered with an eye for modern visual tastes.
The vision of Henry Selick adds a darkness to this sometimes sinister fairy tale.
A (slightly belated) reappraisal of his way of life recalls John Wayne in The Shootist, and evidently this is intended as more than a gore fest. The result is surprisingly dull.
Of Disaster Movie it is difficult to speak, or even think, articulately, a handicap that seems to have afflicted the film's makers.
"Banality of banalities, all is banality," saith the critic emerging from The Duchess as he hums the locations, wigs and furniture.
An uncinematic form, perhaps, but of absorbing interest to cinema-lovers.
movie_title: Never Apologize: A Personal Visit With Lindsay Anderson (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Guy Ritchie's latest is not as bad as his critics, professional and amateur, hoped.
Nostalgic, gentle, loving: the elegiac mood set against endless rural space inevitably suggests Malick's Days of Heaven. What next from this considerable talent?
Is Anybody There? has so many good intentions and engaging moments it is hard to define why it doesn't quite add up.

Fans will appreciate this more than the casual filmgoer trapped in this high-tech junkyard of not-so-special effects, scarcely noticeable dialogue, incoherent plotting, inconsistent psychology and garbled motivations.
The film ends in infectious good-humour. It seems perfectly calculated for its intended market, unlike Wolverine.

The calm, deadpan chronicling of what, one trusts, is an untypical rural Japanese family suggests a very black comedy. Slightly too long but hypnotically told, beautifully acted and not at all depressing.
movie_title: Funuke Domo, Kanashimi no ai Wo Misero (Funuke Show Some Love, You Losers!) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Just as the story grips you it ends, leaving you mystified beyond the call of the enigmatic plot.
The film, a success on the festival circuit, has been described as "carving, visceral, right in your face... scary, gob-smacking". I merely concur, in case they know where I live.
The film cuddles its Dickensian soft centre in a Mills & Boon soft casing. Où sont les wisecracks d'antan? Almost extinct.
A compelling wake-up call in the form of a feature-length documentary.
This limply directed tale emerges as a case study of an all too familiar type of art crime: the making of bad movies.
The movie succeeds because of its haunting lead performances.
On the surface it seems like a chronicle about desperate people and troubled lives. Yet it's full of rich comic moments and euphoric revelations.
Brian D. Johnson makes a strong transformation from Maclean's film critic to documentary director with this engaging account of the late Al Purdy, the colourful rebel poet who became a CanLit star.

While a plot contrivance late in the day ensures that an opportunity for a climactic battle sequence is not wasted, the film is not really an action epic, but a sweeping story about belief sets in the Arab world.
There are times when it manages to conjure a sense of epic mythological struggle, but these seem mostly accidental.
Comparisons have been made to Battle Royale - and they're not entirely undeserved - but this is a different film, and never feels like a watered down version of anything else.
The majority of the film can't quite live up to this barnstorming first half hour, but it remains a delight throughout, even when the gags become a little more hit and miss.
Intelligent, witty and cine-literate in a charmingly self-referential way, The Cabin in the Woods sets out to do something different and does it with bravado.
The story veers between interesting, boring and borderline incomprehensible.

It hardly needs to be said that the 3D conversion here is nothing more than proficient, that it adds nothing and actually takes away some of the clarity and vividness of the film's varied colour palette.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: It's derivative of many thrillers we've seen in recent years, but the strength of its cast and the technical quality of the action do a lot to make us forget those similarities.
This film was a relief to watch after Singh's bungled action spectacle last year, and while it isn't as good as The Fall, it does at least get him back on track.
I knew after I came out of Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close that I had been manipulated, but I didn't feel it mattered because the film told a story about a grieving family which had weight.
This house party quickly gets to the stage where you're siding with the angry neighbours wanting to shut the thing down.
Underwritten, dramatically shallow and visually disappointing; unlike the myths on which it is based, Immortals will be quickly forgotten.
If it lags in the middle, it can be forgiven, because it has a warm heart despite its inconsistencies
Closing with a cleverly inverted sense of ambiguity, Shame is an effective film both performance-wise and from a technical standpoint.
It's gone from an action franchise with identity to something mostly generic and uninspiring.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film never forgets the truism that this genre can do wonders in papering over its cracks simply by letting you have a good time.
A stylish, self-contained, evocative drama with strong lead performances that overcomes the odd dip here and there to provide a distinct and satisfying experience.
Its grimly realistic style may be off-putting to some viewers, but this is a convincing and effective portrayal of a serial killer.
This is a generally family-friendly affair which isn't interested in getting its hands too dirty.

There are some nice ideas thrown around, and the film works as an analogy (albeit it a heavy-handed one) for modern society's staggeringly unjust division of wealth, but it aims to please the broadest audience possible and suffers for it.
While it is not a stand out in its genre, it overcomes the odd dose of over-familiarity with confident filmmaking and some technical flair.
The script doesn't do enough with the father-son element to keep us involved, and the CGI robot fights aren't sufficiently exciting to make us care about the rest
Burton is supremely comfortable doing this sort of thing, but after Alice in Wonderland and this, one can't help but wish that he'd step outside his comfort zone just a little on the next project.
There are plenty of effective jump scares, and it's nicely shot, but beneath the surface there isn't a great deal going on.
If the deadpan sensibility of the film ultimately leaves it feeling a tad lightweight, that isn't to say that Moonrise Kingdom isn't a funny, witty and well-crafted film.
In the end the clichés and overly repetitive plot structure can't derail what is a well-played, well-shot horror flick.
Illumination Entertainment has dispensed with almost all of Dr Seuss' endearing dialogue, which is a shame, because the film could do with more of a personality of its own.
Thankfully, Taylor and his cast create enough laughs and just enough thrilling set pieces to save the project from being crushed under the weight of its own dreary backstory.
The film is missing the originality and jokes that Phil Lord and Chris Miller brought to the first one, but it has one killer trick up its sleeve in the shape of the foodimals.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Alvarez does show some directorial flair but this is not as frightening as it would like to believe it is, nor as interesting.
That it can't match the classics it takes as inspiration shouldn't be used to condemn it too harshly.
While it feels frustratingly disjointed, The Place Beyond The Pines also possesses moments of real power.
There's good work in here but the climax sadly lacks the emotive punch it's looking for.
There's really very little to complain about in this warp-speed sequel.
The best entry in the franchise so far.
Bigelow tells the story very well, very efficiently, but doesn't really say much about it, which is ironic given the response to the film in some quarters.
Spielberg's opening foray into the timeless world of Hergé's amiable hero does enough to whet our appetite for a second, even if it's far from perfect
It has ideas and, in places, verve, but it can't help but feel like a pretty standard thriller with some big names rather erroneously attached
A compelling, darkly humorous watch.
In the wake of the Oscars, we have an early contender for worst film of the year.

This is a very different film to Audiard's most recent release - the impressive A Prophet - but it has a similar sense of maturity about it, and could well have acting awards aplenty heading its way in the coming months.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This feels like a fairly disposable entry in Eastwood's filmography, and represents a confident if uninspiring start to Lorenz's directorial career.

The sense that the different elements don't really add up to much may well leave some feeling cold; for others, the sharp dialogue and comic beats will produce a similar fondness for the characters that In Bruges' best scenes did.
Is Pitch Perfect this year's Bridesmaids? If by that we mean a thoroughly likable and surprisingly funny comedy, then yes, I suppose it is.
Its misjudged villain and generic action film structure put it some way below the staples of the LA thriller sub-genre.
If the scenes between the four leads had been stronger, it might have been easier to overlook the film's structural and tonal weaknesses, but as it happens they only rescue it in dribs and drabs.
Stone has put together a technically sound and sporadically thrilling thriller, but it drops the ball at the end, and tries to squeeze a bit too much into its runtime.
This is an expensive and lazy rehash that either doesn't understand what made its predecessor popular, or doesn't care.

It's overlong, overblown and couldn't establish a convincing plot if its life depended on it, but it sings at the top of its lungs, and if you haven't gone deaf by the mid-point, you might just find yourself humming along.
You could make a case for shearing a little baggage from the run time, but it's hard to complain too much because the laughs keep coming.
It's unfortunate that the set pieces feel a little derivative of Raimi's films, but that was always likely to be the case given the close proximity of this new film to its predecessors.
The vast expanse of the world's driest place - captured here in all its arid intensity - makes for a fascinating and eerie backdrop.

If you're fundamentally put off by MacFarlane's brand of comedy, Ted's cruder elements may well prove too irksome, but this film does have a sweetness at its heart that is pleasantly unexpected, even if it does follow an extremely predictable plot.
At times it feels a little over-familiar, but this is a confident first feature.
Bar some decent choreography and effects in the trenches sequence, the fantasies are tedious and overall it's overblown and shallow.
The final third of the film, which covers the Sparta tournament in great detail, is a breathless triumph; a genuinely adrenaline pumping crescendo.
In the final third the pace quickens, building toward a well staged climax that at least allows the film to bow out on a high.
The film's funniest moment comes courtesy of Tucci; the writers making swift but brilliant use of adoption humour.
It isn't terrible, but it is hugely disappointing, particularly because it has a nicely established aesthetic and an unusually dark tone.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Certainly the story is contrived in places and the tone only just manages to resurface after an early plunge, but if you're willing to go along with it and get involved, you'd have to have a heart of stone not to be at least a little charmed.
The fact that nothing major really happens, and that the monsters are almost entirely off-screen, ends up being less of a problem than it may initially appear to be.
The narrative feels unfocused at times and the pace is changeable, but give it a chance and the presence of Chow Yun-Fat, at least, will win you over.
It won't blow you away, and in some respects it feels like a missed opportunity, but there is something genuine about the Duplass' film that is pleasing to see.

Building to a bravado climax that suddenly becomes almost apocalyptic in its aesthetic, the film succeeds wholeheartedly in breaking through its inspirations to stand on its own as a great prison movie.

In the end 22 Bullets fails to live up to its potential by descending into a series of 'hits' that, whilst they carry a perverse level of justice that is satisfying on one level, end up diluting the film's sense of character and pathos.

It's difficult to feel attached to it on anything other than an aesthetic level, but it is satisfactorily geeky, funny enough to recommend, and in the end not quite like anything else you'll see in the cinema this year.

Strip away the modern day polish and the bluster of its gimmicky (though admittedly satisfying) cast and you're left with an 80s-esque action spectacle. That's the point, of course, but it isn't enough to earn the film a genuine recommendation.
Exposition heavy, Potter 7: Part One is an entertaining but flawed prelude to the real finale.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This film is saved from complete failure by Cruise, who seems to be having fun and does his best to inject some verve into the lacklustre plot and monotonous chase sequences.

It is hugely impressive that, given what was at stake, Nolan has managed to not only pull this out of the bag, but to absolutely nail it. The film is as all-encompassing as the concept of its title: grand, epic, smart and unforgettable.
Corsini's choice to focus on passion, on selfishness, on sex, unfortunately means that the film can't quite make up its mind and never quite settles the way you expect it to.
In part shaken off the shackles of rumoured script problems to provide an experience that remains entertaining despite some rigidly formulaic filmmaking.
Hot Tub Time Machine won't change your mind about this type of comedy if it doesn't appeal to you, but you could do much worse than choosing to see this if comedy is what you're after.
If the cast are to be thanked for raising this film above standard fare, then so too should the writers, who've produced a script that is much much funnier than most people will expect.
The film can't seem to make up its mind whether it wants to be an audience pleasing popcorn treat or a serious, political thriller. It ends up being partly both... with varying degrees of success.

It's certainly more intelligent than your average blockbuster - but it doesn't carry the weight of its convictions.
If it wasn't taking itself so bloody seriously one could at least laugh with it, but as it stands Legion is a film that one can't help but laugh at.
If Cuarón's long-gestating thriller is perhaps not quite the masterpiece we were hoping for, it is still a thrilling and visually striking work.

The film should be commended for updating the story so well, and for allowing a new generation (who may not be interested in the 1984 original, but might love Jaden Smith and Jackie Chan) to appreciate the timeless story.

With a closing reel that will put a smile on your face, Helander's film may feel stretched and a little inconsequential at times, but Rare Exports is a unique take on Christmas cinema and is worthy of your time.

The restaurant-set introduction is a little clunky, and it may be a little overlong (with too many supporting characters), but overall Haggis' film is a competent thriller, subtly directed and well acted.
The ambiguous ending raises a smile rather than a frown, and leaves one hoping that the McDonagh brothers will continue to find charismatic and interesting roles for Brendan Gleeson in films to come.
Sadly, rather than hyping up The Avengers, it left me ruing the fact that we won't see more period Captain America films.
Decent performances are jaded by a hit-and-miss script and are stretched too thin over a high-concept film that doesn't quite manage to find its feet.
Ambitious and spectacular.

It's played pretty straight (though Tavernier allows us a couple of wry laughs) and crucially it maintains the weight of a real drama, as opposed to feeling like a teen romance in a castle (which is essentially what it turns into).

movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There are few greater compliments one can offer a film than to say they feel shorter than they really are, and Bridesmaids' two hours positively flew by.

movie_review_blurb: Proof that Guy Richie can still make good films, though it's not without flaws.
Most kids (and any accompanying parents) will find this to be of a noticeably lower standard than many of the other children's films that have been released recently.

The film rarely depicts violent events, and what set-pieces there are are subtle and short, though well-staged.

Disney's animation renaissance continues apace.

Jesus-who's-come-again asks Himself soul-searching questions in what might've been called The Lack of Passion of the Christ.
